resources.string: Compose Accessibility Techniques
Navigate up
Collapse
Expand
Home
Android Compose Accessibility Techniques Demo App
This application demonstrates a variety of accessibility best practices for Jetpack Compose-based UIs, as well as the problems they can address.
Use the cards below to pick a topic area and follow the directions on the screen regarding the assistive technology employed in that demonstration.
Text alternatives
Provide text alternatives for non-text content when appropriate

All informative non-text content must have a text alternative associated with it, generally via the contentDescription property. Purely decorative content that conveys no meaning must be marked as such with a null contentDescription.
Informative non-text content that is redundant with adjacent text content should be grouped with that text content and given a null contentDescription. See example 4 below.
Turn on TalkBack and read the screen elements for examples.
Bad example 1: Sunrise and sunset times and icons with empty text alternatives
OK example 2: Sunrise and sunset times and icons with text alternatives
Sunrise
Sunset
Good example 3: Sunrise and sunset times grouped with their icons
Good example 4: Sunrise and sunset times grouped with their icons and redundant text
Note that almost all example headings in this app use a similar technique.
Good example 5: Sunrise and sunset times and icons with group text alternatives
Sunrise at 6:24am
Sunset at 5:35pm
Bad example 6: A \'Share\' icon button with an empty text alternative
Share icon with an empty text alternative clicked.
Note that the \'Share\' icon with an empty text alternative cannot be selected with TalkBack.
Bad example 7: A \'Share\' icon button with a null text alternative
Share icon with a null text alternative clicked.
Good example 8: A \'Share\' icon button with a text alternative
Share
Share icon with text alternative clicked.
Bad example 9: Decorative images with empty contentDescription
Example decorated text.
Bad example 10: Decorative images with text alternatives
Sprout
Example decorated text.
Good example 11: Decorative images with null contentDescription
Example decorated text.
OK example 12: Grouped decorative images with invisibleToUser()
Sprout
Example decorated text.
Good example 13: Grouped decorative images with null contentDescription
Example decorated text.
Content group replacement
Grouped content can be replaced to enhance screen reader experience

Sometimes the graphical components of a layout group do not convey their meaning well to screen readers, even if grouped into a single text. In this case, replace the screen reader text for the layout group with something better.
Turn on TalkBack and listen to the items on this page for a demonstration.
Bad example 1: Rating with content ungrouped
Bad example 2: Rating with content grouped
Note how the LinearProgressIndicator is announced separately in TalkBack, despite the Row\'s merge semantics.
Good example 3: Rating with grouped content replaced with invisibleToUser()
Good example 4: Rating with grouped content replaced with mergeAndSetSemantics
Rating:
Reviews: %1$d

plurals.name: content_group_replacement_rating_group_content_description
plurals.item: Rating: %1$s out of %2$s stars, based on %3$d review
Rating: %1$s out of %2$s stars, based on %3$d reviews

resources.string: Heading semantics
Heading text must be marked as an accessibility heading
Accessibility headings both convey the semantic meaning that text is a heading to a screen reader user and allow heading navigation in screen readers.
Turn on TalkBack and read the following text for examples. Switch TalkBack to use the Reading Control \"Headings\" and swipe down and up to experience heading navigation.
Bad example 1: Big text that is not a heading
Graphically large text won\'t act as a heading for accessibility purposes by itself; it must be marked as a heading.
Bad example 2: Ending contentDescription with \'Heading\' is not a heading
%1$s, Heading.

Marking a Composable with a contentDescription that appends \"Heading\" to the text does not give that Composable accessibility heading semantics. The large text above might announce \"Heading\" in TalkBack, but it is not recognized as having that role by the TalkBack \"Headings\" Reading Control.
Good example 3: Use semantics heading() property
Composables can be marked as accessibility headings by adding the Modifier.semantics heading() property.
Interactive control labels
Associate interactive controls programmatically with labels
Turn on TalkBack and swipe through this page to hear demonstrations of interactive controls with and without programmatically-associated labels.
Bad example 1: TextField without associated field label
Text not associated with TextField
Good example 2: TextField automatically associates label and uses as hint
Associated field label/hint
Bad example 3: CheckBox without associated field label
Text not associated with CheckBox
Good example 4: CheckBox with associated field label
Field label associated with CheckBox
Bad example 5: Switch without associated field label
Text not associated with Switch
Good example 6: Switch with associated field label (text)
Field label associated with Switch
Bad example 7: RadioButton group without associated field labels, etc.
Text not associated with RadioButton 1
Text not associated with RadioButton 2
Good example 8: RadioButton group with associated field labels, etc.
RadioButton group label
Field label for RadioButton 1
Field label for RadioButton 2
Good example 9: Button with associated label
Button label
Accordion controls
Accordion controls require an expand or collapse semantics property
Accordion controls must declare the appropriate Modifier.semantics expand() or collapse() action property, depending on their collapsed/expanded state, in addition to any tap to toggle action.
There are many ways to code these controls - as layout elements or list items, but all require this additional semantics in order to announce their expanded/collapsed state.
Turn on TalkBack, navigate the page, and activate the controls for a demonstration. Listen for expanded/collapsed state announcement as well as special expand/collapse actions.
Bad example 1: Accordion without expand/collapse actions
Incorrect Accordion example, Item 1
Incorrect Accordion example, Item 2
Incorrect Accordion example, Item 3
Good example 2: Accordion with expand/collapse actions
Correct Accordion example, Item 1
Correct Accordion example, Item 2
Correct Accordion example, Item 3
Correct Accordion example, Item 4
